content.title: Temporal Artery Biopsy for Giant Cell Arteritis
content.definition: A surgical diagnostic procedure involving excision of a segment of the superficial temporal artery to confirm the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis through histopathologic examination.

concepts.definition: When to perform temporal artery biopsy.

clinical_features.clinical_suspicion: New headache in patient >50 years with elevated ESR/CRP
clinical_features.symptoms: Scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, visual symptoms
clinical_features.ultrasound_negative: Negative ultrasound but high clinical suspicion

clinical_features.vessel_identification: Palpate or use ultrasound to mark course
clinical_features.anesthesia: Local anesthesia with lidocaine, avoid epinephrine

concepts.definition: When to biopsy relative to treatment.

clinical_features.steroids: Do not delay steroids for biopsy if high clinical suspicion
clinical_features.yield: Positive findings persist for 2-6 weeks after starting steroids
clinical_features.visual_symptoms: Start steroids immediately if visual symptoms present

concepts.definition: Microscopic features of giant cell arteritis.

clinical_features.classic: Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells
clinical_features.skip_lesions: Patchy involvement may cause false negatives

clinical_features.contralateral_biopsy: Consider if first biopsy negative but suspicion remains high
clinical_features.complications: Hematoma, wound infection, facial nerve injury (rare)

sources.reference: Hellmich B et al. 2018 Update of the EULAR recommendations for the management of large vessel vasculitis. Ann Rheum Dis. 2020;79:19-30
Muratore F et al. J Autoimmun. 2018;96:15-22
Dasgupta B et al. BSR and BHPR guidelines for the management of giant cell arteritis. Rheumatology. 2010;49:1594-1597

learning_objectives: Identify indications for temporal artery biopsy
Perform temporal artery biopsy with appropriate technique
Understand timing relative to steroid therapy
clinical_pearls: NEVER delay steroids for biopsy if clinical suspicion high, especially with visual symptoms
Minimum 2cm specimen length - longer (3-4cm) increases yield due to skip lesions
Biopsy remains positive for 2-6 weeks after starting steroids
Sensitivity only 70-80% - negative biopsy does not rule out GCA
Consider contralateral biopsy if first negative but suspicion remains high
Avoid epinephrine in local anesthetic - may cause vasoconstriction
